issue.title: std::format #b, #B, #o, #x, and #X presentation types misformat negative numbers

discussion.p: According to both the specification for '#' and the presentation types b, B, o, x, and X (which redundantly duplicate the rule for the relevant prefixes), the string 0b, 0B, 0, 0x, or 0X is prefixed to the result of to_chars. That means:

I assume that's a bug?
(Additionally, if the + specifier is used, there appears to be no specification of where the sign is inserted into the output.)
Victor Zverovich:
Yes. I suggest replacing

blockquote.p: adds the respective prefix "0b" ("0B"), "0", or "0x" ("0X") to the output value
inserts the respective prefix "0b" ("0B"), "0", or "0x" ("0X") to the output value after the sign, if any,

discussion.p:
I think the duplicate wording in the presentation types b, B, o, x, and X can be dropped.
Regarding the + specifier problem: How about adding

blockquote.p: The sign is inserted before the output of to_chars.

discussion.note: 2019-08-21 Priority set to 2 based on reflector discussion

blockquote.p: This wording is relative to N4830.

li.p: Modify the sign options Table [tab:format.sign] in as indicated:

tr.td: Indicates that a sign should be used for both non-negative and negative numbers. The sign is inserted before the output of to_chars.
Indicates that a sign should be used only for negative numbers (this is the default behavior).
Indicates that a leading space should be used for non-negative numbers, and a minus sign for negative numbers.

blockquote.p: -6 The # option causes the alternate form to be used for the conversion. This option is only valid for arithmetic types other than charT and bool or when an integer presentation type is specified. For integral types, the alternate form addsinserts the base prefix (if any) specified in Table [tab:format.type.int] to the output value after the sign, if any. […]
This wording is relative to N4830.

li.p: Modify the sign options Table [tab:format.sign] in as indicated:

tr.td: Indicates that a sign should be used for both non-negative and negative numbers. The + sign is inserted before the output of to_chars for non-negative numbers other than the negative zero. [Note: For negative numbers and the negative zero the output of to_chars will already contain the sign so no additional transformation is performed. — end note]
Indicates that a sign should be used only for negative numbers (this is the default behavior).
Indicates that a leading space should be used for non-negative numbers, and a minus sign for negative numbers.

blockquote.p: -6- The # option causes the alternate form to be used for the conversion. This option is only valid for arithmetic types other than charT and bool or when an integer presentation type is specified. For integral types, the alternate form addsinserts the base prefix (if any) specified in Table [tab:format.type.int] to the output value after the sign character (possibly space) if there is one, or before the output of to_chars otherwise. discussion.note: 2020-02 Status to Immediate on Thursday night in Prague.

resolution.p: This wording is relative to N4849.

li.p: Modify the sign options Table [tab:format.sign] in as indicated:

tr.td: Indicates that a sign should be used for both non-negative and negative numbers. The + sign is inserted before the output of to_chars for non-negative numbers other than negative zero. [Note: For negative numbers and negative zero the output of to_chars will already contain the sign so no additional transformation is performed. — end note]
Indicates that a sign should be used only for negative numbers (this is the default behavior).
Indicates that a leading space should be used for non-negative numbers, and a minus sign for negative numbers.

blockquote.p: -6- The # option causes the alternate form to be used for the conversion. This option is only valid for arithmetic types other than charT and bool or when an integer presentation type is specified, and not otherwise. For integral types, the alternate form addsinserts the base prefix (if any) specified in Table [tab:format.type.int] tointo the output value after the sign character (possibly space) if there is one, or before the output of to_chars otherwise.
